main event: A bright green light, slightly larger than a star, was sighted over Augustine Island, Alaska on March 22, 1954.
interesting points: The object appeared to ascend and hover, then descended rapidly and disappeared from view.
The witness initially thought the object was an aircraft navigation light, but it entered their field of vision at a high speed.
The object displayed a bright flash of light like an explosion to the north, and was visible for 2-3 seconds.
The University of Alaska Astronomy Department suggested the object could have been a meteorite or 'fireball' due to the short sighting duration.
There was speculation that the object could have been the reentry of a satellite called '1959 Alfa 2', based on the time and direction of the sighting.
sighted object: bright green light, slightly larger than a star
witnesses: pilot of Northern Consolidated Airlines flight
